text: <@U09N9J1DY|mlatu> has joined the channel
<@U053Q5G4E>: some prefer multiple activities, multiple fragments, some prefer only fragments almost and some prefer only activities. I'm on the multiple activities, multiple fragments team :smile:
I'm with you <@U061HDV96> - use activities and fragments in whichever way is the best fit for your app :simple_smile:
I’m on the “whatever I feel is best depending on the case"
team
Well I just prefer to use activities for every single thing that does something different. Then in that activity fragments for viewpagers, sidebars for tablets (/drawer on phones)...
Are you a professional Android dev <@U061HDV96> ?
Well that depends on what you call professional. I do Android development for my startup, if you consider that professional, then yes.
Ah... I'd call that a yes :simple_smile:
He talks professionally :p
we’re all professionals….according to our linkedIns
I like the fact that when we have stable jobs we are like bums
But when we have our startup or are unemployed, we look like professionals
Bums is an overstatement though, but you know what I mean I guess
haha <@U04U5KS3Z> I guess we are :simple_smile:

The reason I was asking is that I am a professionaly Java dev, but would really like to get in move in to Android development. I build for fun, have one app on the store, but all jobs advertised, as is always the case, require you to have 3 years commercial experience, dozens of apps in the store and know Android inside and out.
Was curious if anyone here does it professionally, and how did you get to do that? :simple_smile:
Any good developer can pick something up. Programming == reading documentation
You'll be fine
I’m doing it for over 2 years „professionally“ now, meaning as day job
i think it’s safe to say quite a few  android devs both here and in the wild came in to it from non-dev backgrounds
myself included
How did you get in to it then <@U04U5KS3Z> ?
I’ve done it as a hobby, some student competitions and now about a year and half nearly as a day job
i learned it on the side while testing payment systems at a major bank
then my friend recruited me for his start up
prior to that i was in managment consulting
Varied jobs then <@U04U5KS3Z> :simple_smile:
managment consulting? that sounds like one of those guys in suits that drives bentleys
:smile:
suits and bentlys….ill let you guess which one of those i didn’t have
suits? oh you poor boy :disappointed:
who would drive his bentley naked?
leather on leather
rawr

PSA: Retrofit 2.0.0-beta1 is out
quick and dirty @ <https://speakerdeck.com/jakewharton/simple-http-with-retrofit-2-droidcon-nyc-2015>

attachments.title: Simple HTTP with Retrofit 2 (Droidcon NYC 2015)
attachments.text: Retrofit has been simplifying HTTP calls for years and this new version is no different. In addition to fixing some long-standing annoyances, there are a handful of new features which make it more powerful than ever. This talk will focus on how the new APIs in Retrofit aid in making HTTP calls as simple as possible for your app. The integration with OkHttp and Okio APIs will be covered to ensure a full understanding of the HTTP stack. Common use-cases and design patterns through more advanced functionality will end the talk. No prior Retrofit, OkHttp, or Okio exposure needed. The content may quickly cover or skip some introductory aspects in order to allow focus on more actionable and useful content. Video: soon!
attachments.fallback: Speaker Deck: Simple HTTP with Retrofit 2 (Droidcon NYC 2015)

idk, maybe my setup is retarded too? I have a BaseDrawerActivity, which all Activities that need the Drawer extend and all I wanted was to Override some method that will be called when you navigate away
that doesn’t sound too complex
wish i got a task that i actually know how to do
everything i’m learning these days is using proprietary unity plugins
probably need to find a job working with native android again sometime :x
im guessing the basedraweractivity load a common layout, and all the drawer items are fragments?
or new activities
yeah, the drawer entries are all launching activities since I  build this by the "one activity per use case" apporach
deeper navigation then happens in fragments
I'd have to work a bit harder on the de-coupling of the stuff, but there is no fragment re-use anyway since the use cases are fundamentally different
interesting, ive not encountered apps with multiple 'drawer activities'
well, I have to say the navigation is kinda weird, but that is the way UX wants it to be
it goes: Splashscreen -> Login -> Dashboard (duplicates the drawer...) -> Use case roots
and the dashboard AND the use case roots have the drawer
the Play Store has multiple activities with the same drawer
ah fair point <@U0546MZGX>
not that I like that approach but… :stuck_out_tongue:
yeah i get a weird feeling about duplicating entire drawer logic
it's not duplicated
oh not in your use case, just looking at the playstore app
ah :smile:
does including a navigation drawer in multiple activities necessitate code duplication?
can’t you abstract it out?
just use includes and merge tags
maybe not code duplication, but definitely drawer creation is happening multiple times

it’s just funny to see how google recommends to simplify your layouts but then they go and create a “new” (not new because it’s the same) drawer for each activity in the play store, or they just get rid of it (youtube) creating more complex UIs and layouts in the process
well there is a little more to it than that
you are talking about a company that has tens of thousands of employees
if team A does something its not a representation of what you ‘should’ be doing
yup. and they released material design in the hopes of unifying android’s design
do what matias duarte says not what the random teams do
if they can’t do it themselves, how are they expecting every one else to follow suit?
sure but that takes time
a lot of other major companies have not complied yet either
think of google as a bunch of major companies
they aren’t all in the same office getting the same data working on the same things
yeah I understand. but for example youtube always had the “standard” android share icon. and they are using a new one now.
that’s confusing
right but youtube isn’t even on the main google campus
they are their own island, literally
haha
it might be A/B testing through that app
but they changed from something “standard” to something “not standard"
why?
if it works for youtube they’ll push it to others
im not defending that them ignoring their own standards just saying you can’t use google as an example to follow anymore than you can use facebook as an example to follow
they have different teams and they dont have jurisdiction over each other
I know that. but if you launch guidelines to unify “web, desktop and mobile”, and right within your company you are changing apps that used to comply to those guidelines…. I just don’t get it
I think it doesn’t send the right message out there
i understand what you are saying but again, google is a bunch of islands
the android team has no hard relationship with any other segment of google expect for that fact they both work for the same parent company

I don't think there is a "right" message. Google regularly releases good "coding" practices, but honestly if you're looking for a uniform way of defining android's UI, just go to iOS. Android is meant to be unique and therefore won't have a "guideline" to follow.
this is most comical when you hear chet talking about how other teams couldn’t figure out how to use certain API's
they have an internal google +
that’s how they communicate
i’m with you adrian, i don’t see how they release a spec like that and then product managers just do their own thing instead. it might be a big company but the messages are conflicting for sure

its up to everyone else to follow them
not even google uses google+ :troll:
also they are just guidelines

So in the iOS world, I can programmatically make a view and set the position of it to and the add it to another view. Is it possible to do roughly the same thing on the Android side? Do I have to use an XML file that I then inflate and append to the current view? I tried it with the “inflate an XML view” but so far nothing is showing up (no different from the view before I tried to add to it).
post your code
there’s a parameter in View.inflate called attachToRoot which tripped me up when trying to do something like that
or maybe it’s in LayoutInflater.inflate
okay, I’ll check for that and come back if still broken (along w/ posting code) — thanks
yeah i think instead of using attachToRoot I ended up just passing false and calling ViewGroup.addView or something like that
“set position” of a view can be confusing though
hmm yeah i’m not sure what you meant by setting the position <@U094L59R7>
what type of view are you trying to inflate into what type of view?
it’s a bit complicated — I’m working on something else that I have to finish so I’ll come back w/ code
but it’s basically a RecyclerView (using RecyclerViewPager) and I want to put some more views on top of the first page
